newsitem.title: USA: U.S. Treasuries end higher after NAPM-led rally.
newsitem.headline: U.S. Treasuries end higher after NAPM-led rally.

text.p: Optimism that the Federal Reserve would leave monetary policy unchanged at its meeting this week drove the prices of U.S. Treasury securities higher Monday.

Investor optimism was fueled by a weaker-than-expected January report from the National Association of Purchasing Management (NAPM), one that indicated some slowing in manufacturing and a sizable drop in supplier deliveries.
The 30-year long bond ended 19/32 higher at 96 30/32 to yield 6.74 percent, down from 6.79 percent late Friday.

"The (Wall) Street got very complacent to the short and when the NAPM numbers hit -- numbers that were favorable for the Fed remaining on hold -- we had a lot of short covering. Some people were forced back into the market," said a trader at a primary dealership.
It was a day that also saw the return of retail investors.
"I trade the front of the curve and all I heard were people telling me to bid," the trader said.
The NAPM quashed any lingering doubts among many investors that the Fed's Federal Open Market Committee (FOMC) would vote to tighten policy at its meeting Tuesday and Wednesday.

"The economy remains vigorous. Nonetheless we are seeing some slowing in the first quarter and the market has responded to incipient signs of that," said Richard Berner, chief economist at Mellon Bank Corp. in Pittsburgh. Many of the factors that contributed to the 4.7 percent increase in fourth quarter growth simply were one-time events or unsustainable, he said.

The next major reading on the economy comes Friday with the January employment report. A Reuters consensus called for the creation of 237,000 payrolls, a 5.2-percent jobless rate, and a 0.2-percent gain in average hourly earnings.
Berner said payrolls may show some consolidation, but he still saw solid growth of at least 3.0 percent in the first half of 1997.

"Given that we are a relatively high-yield economy, there's a lot of incentive to move money into our markets, especially from Japan," Berner said, a factor that will continue to support the bond market.
Also underpinning bond prices are hopes a deal can be worked out in Washington on a balanced budget by 2002.
"Both sides are showing a lot of comity and good feeling, but I'm skeptical they'll reach agreement," Berner said.
Kathy Bostjancic, money market analyst at UBS Securities Inc., said trading activity slowed after the initial flareup in wake of the NAPM release.
Much of the early trading activity was the result of dealers scrambling to cover shorts, Bostjancic said. Volume fell off throughout the remainder of the session.
"With the FOMC meeting, people are just going to sit tight for a while -- even though there's virtually no expectation of a change in monetary policy," Bostjancic said.
As-expected and largely ignored were small rises in December U.S. personal income and personal spending.

The Treasury Department's auction of three- and six-month bills produced averages of 5.00 percent and 5.08 percent, respectively. The Fed intervened during its usual midmorning period by injecting reserves into the banking system via a round of overnight system repurchase agreements.

Also posting gains on Monday were the two-year note, up 3/32 at 100-even and at 5.87 percent, the five-year, up 7/32 at 100-7/32 and at 6.20 percent, and the 10-year note, up 12/32 at 100-12/32 and 6.45 percent.
